node.title: ‘I Don’t Want to Die for It’: School Board Members Face Rising Threats
node.description: Across the country, parents have threatened board members and vandalized their homes. One board member scans his driveway before walking to his car.

node.title: ‘We serve a God who is not asleep’: Clergy urges unity for Ahmaud Arbery’s family
node.description: Clergy members asked the community to remain peaceful despite their unhappiness that a nearly all-white jury had been seated in the trial of the white men accused of killing Ahmaud Arbery, a Black man.

node.title: More People Googling 'How To Buy Fake Vaccine Cards' As January 4 Mandate Deadline Nears
node.description: Searches for counterfeit cards have surged since the Occupational Safety and Health Administration announced the mandate deadline and details on November 4.

node.title: Merck and Pfizer COVID Pills Compared As Paxlovid Appears to Cut Deaths
node.description: Almost two years since the start of the pandemic, more drugs to treat COVID patients may be on their way.

node.title: China Criticizes Press Freedom Survey That Shows Journalists Want to Leave Hong Kong
node.description: Eighty-three of 99 participants said the journalism environment has "changed for the worse" after a law was adopted in response to pro-democracy protests.

node.title: Pfizer, Merck COVID Pills Could Be Key to Ending Pandemic
node.description: Barring a vaccination surge, oral antivirals could be America's next best bet in returning to normal because they could reduce strains on health care systems.

node.title: Idaho Man Dies of Rabies in State's First Fatal Case Since 1978
node.description: Although the man didn't think he had been bitten or scratched, he did come into close contact with an infected bat, authorities said.

node.title: Police Beg Judge Not to Release Man Arrested 3 Times in 24 Hours
node.description: Robert Avila was arrested for a third time nine hours after his second arrest and now an officer is using an arrest affidavit to ask a judge not to release him.

node.title: What to Cook This Weekend
node.description: Practicing for Thanksgiving always helps, and now is the time to start.

node.title: Ronnie Wilson, Founder of the Gap Band, Dies at 73
node.description: After beginning his career as a teenager, he joined with his two younger brothers to record R&B hits like “You Dropped a Bomb on Me” and “Outstanding.”

node.title: Those Loud and Polluting Leaf Blowers
node.description: Readers mostly excoriate and urge alternatives to what one calls “these obnoxious, deafening, exhaust-spewing machines.” Also: The metaverse; signs of concern.

node.title: Owner Says French Bulldog Choked on Dog Biscuit in Starbucks 'Puppuccino'
node.description: Megan Harrison said she was "absolutely disgusted" by Starbuck's response to her puppy's death after she was offered a £250 voucher as compensation.

node.title: Ex-Macron Aide Convicted of Assault and Posing as a Police Officer
node.description: The aide, Alexandre Benalla, who was fired in 2018 after videos emerged of him beating a man at a labor protest, was sentenced to serve a year of house arrest with electronic monitoring.

node.title: When Bad News About the Climate Is Good for Green Stocks
node.description: Markets respond when coverage of global warming spikes, new research suggests. But investors could become inured to the bleak state of climate change.

node.title: Bald Eagles Filmed Fighting in Minnesota Street: 'It's Just Crazy'
node.description: A police officer who responded to the scene said: "It's definitely one of the most memorable calls I've been on."

node.title: Virginia Loss Was Bad for Joe Biden, Could Be Even Worse for Donald Trump
node.description: Glenn Youngkin's winning campaign could be a sign that Trump-style politics can succeed without him.

node.title: With Predominantly White Jury Sworn In, Trial Begins in Shooting Death of Ahmaud Arbery
node.description: Greg McMichael, his adult son Travis McMichael, and their neighbor William "Roddie" Bryan are facing murder and other felony charges.

node.title: Google Temps Fought Loss of Pandemic Bonus. And Won.
node.description: When a Google staffing agency reneged on a promise to pay an attendance bonus, temps who are part of the company’s union organized and forced it to backtrack.

node.title: Remains in Colorado Are Believed to Be West German Hiker Missing Since 1983
node.description: Rudi Moder, who was described as an experienced winter mountaineer, disappeared nearly 40 years ago during a skiing trip in Rocky Mountain National Park.

node.title: Near-Daily Covid Tests, Sleeping in Classrooms: Life in Covid-Zero China
node.description: Residents in Ruili, in southwestern China, have been locked down four times in the past year as part of the country’s quest to eliminate the virus.

node.title: ‘Les Éternels’: les super-franchises redescendent sur Terre
node.description: Après “Nomadland", Oscar du Meilleur Film, la réalisatrice Chloé Zhao s’essaie au blockbuster avec le dernier-né des Marvel, un casting séduisant à l’appui.

node.title: How to Track Runners in the New York City Marathon.
node.description: Spectators can track runners online and on an app in real time on race day.

node.title: The Metaverse Takes Manhattan
node.description: NFT.NYC, a gathering for nonfungible token enthusiasts, offered a taste of a crypto-filled future.

node.title: A Body Donated for Science Was Dissected for a Paying Audience
node.description: The widow of David Saunders, 98, said she did not know the body of her husband, who died of Covid-19, would be taken apart at an Oregon hotel where audience members paid up to $500 to attend.

node.title: Vietnamese upset after video emerges of Salt Bae feeding gold-leaf steak to security minister
node.description: A video showing Salt Bae feeding a powerful Vietnamese official morsels of steak smothered in gold leaf at a luxury London restaurant sparks anger in the South-East Asian country, where the average person earns a few dollars a day.

node.title: The Jobs Numbers Take the ‘Stag’ Out of the Stagflation Scare
node.description: Americans are going back to work at a rapid clip.

node.title: 11 states sue the Biden administration over its vaccination mandate for large companies.
node.description: The lawsuit was filed a day after the announcement of a Jan. 4 deadline for the companies to begin their mandates or start weekly testing.

node.title: Internet Supports Mom Whose Partner Won't Put Her in His Will
node.description: The mom explained that she has chosen to leave the house she pays for in the will to her partner, but that he wants all his inheritance to go their daughter instead.

node.title: Pfizer COVID Pill Prevents 89 Percent of Hospitalizations—How It Compares to Merck's
node.description: Oral antivirals such as the ones from Pfizer and Merck could be key to the COVID-19 response by keeping people out of the hospital.

node.title: Immunocompromised girl among first to get vaccine: "Yay!"
node.description: Ella Conrad's mom started listening to doctors and following the science — going from a QAnon follower to a vaccine advocate for her state.

node.title: Watch the 1960s Come Alive in ‘Last Night in Soho’
node.description: Edgar Wright narrates a dreamy sequence from his film featuring Thomasin McKenzie and Anya Taylor-Joy.

node.title: Here are the charges that the defendants face.
node.description: Taken together, the charges provide a number of different ways that the defendants, Gregory McMichael, Travis McMichael and William Bryan, could wind up facing life in prison if they are convicted.

node.title: Jacob Wohl Says Jews Must Have Christmas Decorations To Assimilate in U.S.
node.description: The conspiracy theorist's remarks were rejected by users of the controversial "free speech" network Gab.

node.title: Man fatally shot by Rittenhouse "was reaching" for gun, witness says
node.description: The killing of Joseph Rosenbaum has emerged as one of the most crucial and disputed moments of the night.

node.title: House poised to vote on infrastructure and Build Back Better bills
node.description: The House is expected to vote on the two key pieces of President Biden's agenda Friday.

node.title: Ron DeSantis' 2024 Chances Increase as GOP Learns to Sell Trumpism Without Trump
node.description: One expert said the Florida Governor's presidential ambitions largely depend on what Donald Trump decides to do in 2024,

node.title: ‘Justice for my daughter’: Parents issue a plea on air pollution.
node.description: A letter to world leaders gathered at the U.N. climate conference in Glasgow was signed by nearly 500 parent groups from 44 countries.

node.title: Snail Mail Turns a Bleeding Heart Into a Spectacular Album
node.description: On her second LP, “Valentine,” the singer and guitarist Lindsey Jordan delivers direct lyrics and wrenching melodies in the service of vivid emotional truths.

node.title: Florida's DeSantis, other GOP states plan to sue over COVID mandate
node.description: The latest ruling from the Biden administration requires businesses with at least 100 employees to mandate COVID vaccines or weekly testing, but some Republicans say it's "unconstitutional."

node.title: Employment rebounded in October with 531,000 new jobs
node.description: Better-than-expected report follows two months of lagging job growth. Employers are hiring as the Delta variant fades.

node.title: Martha Moxley murder: Case timeline
node.description: The murder of a 15-year-old girl rocked a quiet Connecticut town in 1975. A look inside at the case that has frustrated investigators.

node.title: Pfizer Says Its Antiviral Pill Is Highly Effective in Treating Covid
node.description: Pfizer’s is the second pill to show effectiveness against Covid-19, and it is the first purpose-built to attack the virus that causes the disease.

node.title: It’s Sign-Up Time for Federal Health Insurance
node.description: Consumers are likely to see more plan options and lower premiums for next year. “This is a whole new ballgame,” one health expert said.

node.title: Vienna will start to vaccinate young children without E.U. approval.
node.description: Pediatricians in the Austrian capital will authorize the off-label use of the BioNTech-Pfizer vaccine for children starting next Friday.

node.title: Snow Gritter Named After Prince Philip Crowned 'The Duke of Spreadingborough'
node.description: North Lincolnshire Council paid tribute to the late royal, who died earlier this year.

node.title: U.S. Adds Over Half a Million New Jobs in October, More Than Analysts Expected
node.description: The unemployment rate edged downward from 4.8 percent to 4.6 percent last month.

node.title: The Highest Vaccination Rate in California
node.description: Once an anti-vaccine stronghold, Marin County has become an unlikely champion of Covid-19 shots. But will it last?

node.title: Bosnia Must Join NATO 'Soon as Possible' Minister Says as Russia Looms Over Serb Crisis
node.description: Foreign Minister Bisera Turkovic told Newsweek in an exclusive interview that EU and NATO membership is the only guarantee of peace and stability.

node.title: Russian Diplomat Found Dead Outside Embassy in Germany: Report
node.description: "Der Spiegel" reported on Friday that a 35-year-old man had been found outside Moscow's mission in Berlin.

node.title: Jenna Ryan, Jailed Over January 6, Tells Critics: 'I'm Going to Prison…Pop Champagne'
node.description: The real estate agent, who claimed her blonde hair and white skin would keep her out of jail, responds after she was handed a 60-day sentence.

node.title: Can Dogs Tell If You're Injured or Sick?
node.description: Dogs are incredibly intuitive, with some suggesting they are able to sense everything from danger to their owners' mood changes - but can they tell if a human is injured or sick?

node.title: How COVID contributed to a worrying spike in female suicides in Japan
node.description: While the rates of suicides by men and full-time working women dropped, the overall figure was up, and women without stable employment seem to have been hit hardest.

node.title: Deal scrapped between feds and firm behind J&J COVID vaccine mix-up
node.description: Emergent BioSolutions says it will continue making COVID-19 vaccine for Johnson & Johnson under a separate deal.

node.title: Navy fires officers of U.S. nuclear sub damaged in collision
node.description: The Navy has yet to publicly explain how or why the USS Connecticut struck an underwater mountain.

node.title: Is the clue to finding a killer in the diary of a 15-year-old girl?
node.description: After Martha Moxley was beaten to death with a golf club outside her home in upscale Greenwich, Connecticut, investigators suspected her neighbors – cousins of the Kennedys – knew something about the murder.

node.title: Don’t Throw Away That Ancient Pink Toilet. Someone Out There Wants It.
node.description: Retro-minded homeowners are driving across the country and paying thousands of dollars to restore or recreate a vintage bathroom or kitchen.

node.title: Remaking Diana: Six Faces of a Princess to Stream Online
node.description: The film “Spencer” is the latest in a long line of TV and movie depictions of Diana. Here’s a selection.

node.title: Rights Groups Urge Singapore Not to Execute Man With Mental Disability
node.description: The man, a Malaysian with an I.Q. of 69, was caught trying to smuggle an ounce and a half of heroin in 2009. Some are calling his planned hanging a human rights violation.

node.title: Man To Plead Guilty After Charges of Buying Animal Parts, Such As Bear Paws
node.description: Prosecutors alleged that Yan Fong met with an undercover game warden who was purportedly selling illegally obtained wildlife parts and carcasses.

node.title: Watch 'Flying Cars' Racing in the Desert Ahead of New Motorsport Series
node.description: The video shows the electric flying vehicles zoom along a drag strip at speeds of around 100 miles per hour ahead of a full-scale competition.

node.title: At least 18 billionaires got stimulus checks, report says
node.description: Some 270 ultra-wealthy people who received the checks had reported negative net incomes on their tax returns, according to ProPublica.

node.title: Tomb of the Unknowns Welcomes the Public for First Time in 73 Years
node.description: Since 1948, guards have kept tourists and other visitors away from the memorial at Arlington National Cemetery. For two days this month, they will be allowed to get close and place flowers at the tomb.

node.title: Spending Bill Live Updates: House Democrats Set to Vote on $1.85tn Package
node.description: House Democrats are set to vote on both the social spending and infrastructure bills after weeks of intense negotiations. Follow Newsweek's liveblog for all the latest.

node.title: Who is JaShyah Moore? Teen Missing for Three Weeks After Vanishing in New Jersey
node.description: The 14-year-old girl, who lives in East Orange, was last seen wearing khaki pants, a black jacket and black boots.

node.title: Virginia: What was behind the shift of White women toward the GOP?
node.description: A look at the exit polls tell us. In 2020, they were roughly split in their vote for the president. This year, they backed Youngkin by 14 points.

node.title: What's behind the push for a fourth stimulus check
node.description: IRS has distributed almost 170 million payments. But hardship remains widespread as the Delta variant spreads.

node.title: Deere says it's done bargaining with striking workers
node.description: More than half of workers rejected the equipment maker's latest offer, which included a 10% pay hike.

node.title: House set to vote Friday on revised social spending plan and infrastructure
node.description: The new version now contains a provision that had been dropped, paid leave, and also includes a tax break for wealthier Americans.

node.title: New COVID pill cut hospital and death risk by 89%, Pfizer says
node.description: Pfizer said it will ask the FDA and international regulators to authorize its pill as soon as possible.

node.title: What Is Theranos CEO Elizabeth Holmes' Net Worth As Founder Faces Federal Charges?
node.description: Elizabeth Holmes, the founder of the defunct blood testing company Theranos  was charged with various counts of fraud and could face prison time and other penalties if convicted.

node.title: Video appears to show Ruggs III's car moments before deadly crash
node.description: Police reports say the now-released Las Vegas Raider star's car was going 156 mph. A young woman and her dog were killed.

node.title: What to Know About ‘Eternals’
node.description: Who are they? How long have they been here? Where do they fit in the Marvel Cinematic Universe? We have answers.

node.title: Incredible Video of Scar-covered Great White Shark Goes Viral
node.description: Dean Spraakman, who filmed the 9.8-foot apex predator, said to his knowledge no one has ever seen a great white so badly beaten up.

node.title: 2 killed in dramatic shootout on beach as tourists run for cover
node.description: Authorities said the commando wore ski masks and arrived by boat at the beach, and they fled in a boat after the attack.

node.title: Alabama County Runs TikTok Contest With Prizes To Encourage Vaccinations
node.description: The state has one of the lowest vaccination rates in the U.S., leading to initiatives to change that.

node.title: Iran claims big boost in uranium enrichment ahead of new nuke talks
node.description: Tehran says it has 25 kilos of uranium enriched to 60% purity, the latest effort to boost its negotiating power as hope fades for a revived nuclear agreement.

node.title: COVID-19 Live Updates: Another 500,000 more deaths by February Predicted
node.description: The WHO has warned of a further 500,000 COVID-19 deaths between now and February as countries brace for a winter spike. Follow Newsweek's liveblog for all the latest.

node.title: College Football Playoff Rankings Are an Ode to the Power 5
node.description: The rankings showed how much organizers favor the most powerful teams in the sport, and they created a hurdle for Cincinnati, which has a marquee win and an undefeated record.

node.title: Turning Back the Clock
node.description: After a busy week, we offer six stories that caught our eyes.

node.title: Japan will shorten quarantine for business travelers to 3 days.
node.description: The easing of rules comes as cases decline significantly. The country has virtually closed its borders since the start of the pandemic.

node.title: 6 Companies Most Likely to Next Join Tesla on $1 Trillion Valuation
node.description: Elon Musk's company joined the exclusive $1 trillion club last week—joining Apple, Saudi Aramco, Microsoft, Amazon and Alphabet.

node.title: Multiple States Sue Joe Biden Administration Over Work Vaccine Mandates
node.description: Under the new rules, businesses with 100 employees or more are required to develop a mandatory vaccination and testing policy within 30 days.

node.title: David Pogue and his quest to make scientific achievements relatable
node.description: On "The Takeout" podcast this week, Pogue talks about the mission for his new podcast series "Unsung Science."

node.title: What To Know About NASA's Asteroid Impact Mission To Test Earth's Defences
node.description: Scientists want to know if smashing the DART spacecraft into the Dimorphos asteroid system at 15,000 miles per hour could protect our planet from possible future impacts.

node.title: Jim Jones Vows to Kill Whoever is Trying to Poison Him in Disturbing Audio
node.description: Jim Jones believed someone at Jonestown was trying to poison him, which is ironic given that he was planning to poison his entire congregation.

node.title: Feds scrap deal with company that made contaminated J&J COVID vaccine
node.description: Emergent BioSolutions says it will lose $180 million of the $600 million called for in the original contract, and says the decision was mutual.

node.title: Here’s what to watch for in the October jobs report.
node.description: Economists are looking for a gain of 450,000 positions, with a tailwind from hiring by leisure and hospitality businesses.

node.title: Wages are rising, but can they keep up with inflation?
node.description: In the tug of war between wage growth and rising prices, it is not yet clear who is winning. It could matter for the Fed.

node.title: Young Activists Want Action as Protesters Rally at COP26
node.description: For many, the climate conference has inspired mixed emotions: concern that their voices were not really being listened to, but also hope that their presence would help drive change.

node.title: Cancun Shooting Video Shows Resort Guests Hide As Armed Men Storm Beach
node.description: The group arrived by boat in front of resorts in Cancun on Mexico's Caribbean coast in an apparent fight between warring drug gangs.

node.title: New Jersey Truck Driver Edward Durr's Offensive Social Media Posts Emerge
node.description: The GOP candidate—who won a shock victory against Stephen Sweeney—previously called Islam a "cult of hate" and its prophet Muhammad a "pedophile" online.

node.title: Baby Gorilla at Ohio Zoo Adopted by Elder Female After Mom's Lack of Care
node.description: The young western lowland gorilla, the first to be born at Cleveland Zoo, is being cared for by the oldest female in the group, who takes it to be fed by humans.

node.title: Floods kill at least six people in Indonesia as thick mud hampers relief efforts
node.description: Flash flooding caused by torrential rains on Indonesia's main island of Java have killed at least six people, with three others missing.

node.title: Kangaroo Island Mayor storms out of parliamentary inquiry after refusing to answer lawyer's questions
node.description: Describing it as a "complete circus", Michael Pengilly storms out of a parliamentary committee looking into Vickie Chapman's refusal of a port on Kangaroo Island.

node.title: If you support Taiwan's independence, China won't let you into the mainland, Hong Kong, or Macau
node.description: The Chinese government says it has drawn up a list of people who support Taiwan's independence.

node.title: Beyond Ocean Views: Homes Perched on Cliffs
node.description: It takes some creative engineering — and a bit of daredevil spirit — to build a house that is truly waterside.

node.title: On the Portuguese Coast, an Appealing Spot for Seaside Homes
node.description: It wasn’t too long ago that Comporta was relatively unknown, but it’s seeing a spurt of development and now may be the time to buy.

node.title: Another Landmark Lost, This Time on Astor Row in Harlem
node.description: A building that is protected from demolition in New York City may seem safe, but decades of neglect and missed opportunities can take a toll.

node.title: An Adventure in the Conventional
node.description: Jessica Rosenblum was initially more interested in redecorating Steve Young’s loft apartment than she was in him.

node.title: Landmarks Aren’t Always Forever
node.description: Here are a few historic structures that were demolished and one that was spared after being declared a landmark at the 11th hour.
